My maternal grandmother had Pseudobulbar affect (PBA) she cried inedibly easily. Even in a completely neutral setting like a grocery store or eating lunch if someone looked at her and said, 'Oh love, don't cry.' Even if she hasn't been crying before. Nothing had happened. Just that was enough to cause her to tear up and cry for the next several minutes.

I always felt bad when my grandpa would gently tease her about it at Sunday dinners, which would make her cry, which made him chuckle. I don't think he meant it maliciously. I only saw him do it at Sunday dinners with family: her dad (my great grandpa), her siblings (my great aunt and great uncle), her kids (my mom & Aunt and their spouses) and us, grandkids at Sunday dinner.

Looking back I think he found it an endeering quality of hers-- that she was so tenderhearted. Although she smiled through her tears and handled his 'teasing' with grace, I think it was embarrassing for her. She was a pretty introverted/quiet person.

I'm nowhere near as sensitive as she was, but I wonder if I inherited a little Psudobular affect from her whenever I'm crying at random YouTubes like this. Or maybe it's hormones. 🤷‍♀️

Hello, resident trans man here! I've been taking testosterone for over two years now, and I can say beyond a doubt that I find it significantly harder to produce emotional tears. I cry significantly less than I did before I started testosterone, even when experiencing the same level of emotion. It now takes a MUCH stronger emotional response to cry. I find that I cry pretty easily when near another person that's crying and confiding in me, however when I'm alone, I usually don't cry very often. Maybe.. 8 times a year?? Like I can pinpoint every single time I've cried (and by crying, I mean full sobbing, tears streaming down my face, struggling to breathe). I cried when my dog died, when my sister moved out, and I cried a little when my mom graduated with her BSN. I cry when I feel frustrated and stuck, I find after being angry about the same thing for multiple days that emotion begins to divert to sadness and I'll start crying over it, and I cry when I think about things that made me really happy in the past that I lost before I was ready to move on, like hanging out with my sister (then she moved out and moved across the state) and going to band (I had to drop out of high school during Covid because I have ADHD and I just.. can't learn online. It stresses me out and my mental health rapidly declines, and within a matter of months I become suicidal; because of that, I lost band, where was the only place I've felt truly at home. Music is my therapy, and playing outside of a band setting just isn't the same). I cry the same amount of instinctive tears, like when the sun is really bright or an eyelash is in my eye, but emotional tears are just less common. I NEVER cry from movies or TV shows, though I find I do still cry while reading some books.

I've definitely cried over the bills being passed this year that target specifically trans youth, it's barely May and I can feel that this year is going to be a record low for trans people and I can only hope that people out there see how much it hurts us. I cry for my brothers, sisters, and nonbinary siblings. I fear for their safety. I fear for their lives. I know I would have killed myself if I had to wait until I was 18 to start testosterone. Even waiting for 2 years after hitting puberty (when I first began experiencing body dysphoria) was so distressing that I tried to kill myself, and the only reason I didn't was because my sister hid everything I could've easily hurt myself with, and I didn't want to fail and have to explain to my family what had happened. And my mom and two sisters were incredibly supportive, my dad was not. I had support and I still wanted to die. I can only imagine what other trans people are going through, and how many of them will die because of laws passed that target them. Lawmakers claim that they're protecting children from permanent harm by preventing them from taking hormones until the age of 18. You know what's far more permanent and far more harmful? Death. Most of the effects from HRT can be reversed with no additional effort. Hormones do not make you sterile. In fact I get my period if I go long enough without doing my T shot. I'm getting off topic but I just.. Please be aware of how much these laws are hurting us. Please be aware of how much danger we're in. I'm one of the lucky ones that are soon going to be 18. But even I don't feel safe, because there's already so many loopholes in laws that are meant to protect me. Please don't look the other way. The trans community is a vast minority compared to the cisgender population, we usually need representation from the privileged majority to be seen. Even as a white person in a first world country, I'm afraid to walk alone no matter the time of day because I fear that if someone attacks me, nobody will help. Nobody will care. So many trans people, mostly trans women, are brutally murdered and nobody says their names. Nobody tries to find their murderers. It feels like no one cares. And now, not only are they not helping us, they're attacking us. I know I'm just a stranger on the internet, but if I can open one person's eyes to the unique hardships trans people go through, I'll feel like I've done something. The world doesn't have to be this way, we have the power to change it. History has proven it time and time again.

comment_text: The reason adults still cry when they are sad is because our bodies are trying to release the chemicals in the brain that make us feel sad (catecholamine adrenaline) so that we can return to normal and rational thinking rather than being caught up in an emotion. Our bodies release these chemicals through tears released in the lacrimal sacs. In fact, it’s sort of how when we get angry, we feel very energized and simply have the urge to do something rather violent; because it will allow your body to burn off the chemical and return to rational thinking. That’s my guess. Does it make sense?

I know a person who can just simply control their crying to the point that they can schedule their “crying” session whenever they feel like it as a way to dump their emotional feelings, it seems good, but I feel like it has its drawbacks, would be a nice suggestion to make a video discussing how the mind can control or hone the emotions you may bottle up and how the mind can develop such strength to be able to control the way you can feel, whether it is instinctive as in where you are may either trigger you to either feel distressed from traumatic stress or trigger you to mask your emotions because you’re in a professional environment, which brings up the point of the , “adults don’t cry”, type of mindset. It’s not too hard to study crying, however, most questions are answered differently as the individual’s background differs to their mentality, whether it’s depression, repetitive situations that used to cause stress but due to getting used to the occurrence, they built a mental block which keeps them from being emotionally drained or feel distressed because they’re used to the environment like a kid who hates school and cried about it, which eventually stopped because it came to mind that either you don’t find it necessary anymore or you got used to the routine of waking up early and going to school, however, the reasons as to why or how the person ended up stopping to show emotional distress comes from a case to case bases. It’d be great to discuss more in detail in understanding how crying works and how it could trigger from natural responses (which you have covered mostly in this video) or artificial responses like mental blocks or manipulation.

hey greg, I think you're right about crying being an outward expression of the inability to vocalise emotion into words. like you mentioned, I think laughter is the same thing.

I tried to think of the different times in my life that I had cried. I have often felt the welling up of tears, but it takes me quite a bit to pass the barrier into crying. the times when I have cried, it was associated with moments where I felt the dispair/hoplessness/futility/helplessness of the situation in such a strong way that my rational brain couldn't identify a way for me to quanifty that in a way where I could go forward. instead, I took a moment to cry it out.

as a correlary to this, I often times experience experience bursts of laughter when I receive emotion from someone else that I can't express in words, but it feels really funny to me. ever been to a party and a bunch of people are laughing really hard at a joke you totally didn't understand, but because it feels so fnnny, you laugh right along with them -- even though you don't know what you're laughing at?

---

it seems to me that the mechanism for both laughter and crying happens when you pass a threshold. before crying, there is that feeling of welling up, and before laughing there is also a buildup, where the smile on your face eventually passes to a laugh. this suggests to me that when you hear/see/experience something, it resonates with you and that either makes you feel good or bad (the basic emotional response/reaction). this reaction seems to come from your own perception, or how you interpret the thing that you just saw/heard/experienced.

for example, yesterday a veritasium video came out with bill gates: https://youtu.be/Grv1RJkdyqI?t=320

derek says, "I've got to say that as I was growing up and coming into this information age, it seems like the internet and all of these tools were going to make the correct information so much more easier to access -- and bring us into a more fact based world. instead, it doesn't look as though it's bringing us there."

bill is clearly smiling and holding back laughter.

this suggests to me that based on what I experience and what I postulate to be the mechanism for laughter, this seems to suggest that bill thinks derek's question is hilarious. he must have thought the information age bringing us to more fact-based world bit to be the setup for the punchline of "it doesn't look as though it's bringing us there" being the punchline.

Well, this explains why I hate crying so much.

While there may be no studies about crying in gender non-conforming individuals, I have gathered quite a lot of anecdotal evidence that it is actually hormones that play an important role in crying. Specifically that high levels of testosterone suppress the ability to cry. I'm a transgender woman, and before I started Hormone Replacement Therapy ("still a boy") I cried extremely little. However, once I suppressed my testosterone and increased my estrogen I started to cry substantially more. There are countless sad movies that I had managed to watch and not cry before my transition, but end up sobbing when I watch them now. This is something that many of my trans woman friends have also noticed. On the other hand, when talking to many trans men, most of them say that it's harder to cry and they cry less often after starting to take testosterone.

I definitely believe the "big boys don't cry" mentality (a.k.a. toxic masculinity) has a big role to play too. I was told that a lot growing up, and remember plenty of times where I should've cried but forced myself not to. But I doubt that alone accounts for the difference in frequency of crying.
